items.title: Australian researchers build motor powered by liquid metal

featured_image.name: 2022 | Beyond sci-fi: Researchers manipulate liquid metals ...

items.description:
Researchers at the University of New South Wales have developed a motor that operates using a droplet of liquid metal instead of traditional rigid components—a breakthrough that could reshape the future of soft robotics, flexible electronics, and medical devices.

The tiny device, called a liquid metal droplet rotary paddle motor, generates motion through swirling flows inside a liquid metal droplet embedded in a salt solution and exposed to an electric field. A small copper paddle placed within the swirling metal is carried along by these internal flows, creating rotation at speeds of up to 320 revolutions per minute.[1][2][3]

"This is a completely new way to create motion," said Dr Priyank Kumar, a UNSW Senior Lecturer who supervised the project and served as the corresponding author on a paper published in npj Flexible Electronics. "We're harnessing the flow of liquid metal itself to produce rotation, without any traditional moving parts. It's simple, compact, and inherently flexible".[2][1]

items.title: China's birth rate hits record low as population shrinks again

featured_image.name: China birthrate shrinks to lowest on record as policies fail to to lift births

items.description:
China recorded its lowest birth rate since the founding of the People's Republic in 1949, with just 7.92 million babies born in 2025, according to official data released Monday by the National Bureau of Statistics. The figure represents a 17% decline from the 9.54 million births recorded in 2024, dashing hopes that a modest uptick last year signaled a reversal of the country's deepening demographic crisis.[1][2][3]

The birth rate fell to 5.63 births per 1,000 people, marking the lowest level in more than seven decades of record-keeping. Meanwhile, deaths climbed to 11.31 million, the highest mortality rate since 1968, resulting in a net population decline of 3.39 million. China's total population now stands at 1.405 billion, shrinking for the fourth consecutive year.[4][5][6]

items.title: Trump cites Nobel snub to justify Greenland demand in letter

featured_image.name: Trump tells Norway he no longer feels obligation to think only of peace

items.description:
President Donald Trump has told Norwegian Prime Minister Jonas Gahr Støre that he "no longer feels an obligation to think purely of peace" after being denied the Nobel Peace Prize, using the perceived slight to justify his demand for American control over Greenland in a letter that has sent shockwaves through transatlantic relations.

The letter, first reported by PBS journalist Nick Schifrin on Sunday and confirmed by multiple outlets including Bloomberg and Reuters, was shared by Trump's National Security Council with several European ambassadors in Washington.[1][2][3]

items.title: Trump threatens tariffs on eight nations over bid to buy Greenland

featured_image.name: European leaders slam Trump’s tariff threats over Greenland

items.description:
President Donald Trump's threat to impose escalating tariffs on eight European nations until the U.S. is allowed to buy Greenland has roiled global markets, sent gold and silver to record highs, and prompted European leaders to consider unprecedented countermeasures.

Trump announced Saturday that he would levy a 10% tariff on goods from Denmark, Norway, Sweden, France, Germany, the Netherlands, Finland, and the United Kingdom starting February 1, rising to 25% by June 1 unless an agreement is reached for the "complete and total purchase of Greenland."[1][2][3]

items.title: IMF raises growth forecasts for India and Nigeria in 2026 outlook

featured_image.name: IMF sees steady global growth in 2026 as AI boom offsets ... - Reuters

items.description:
The International Monetary Fund on Monday upgraded economic growth forecasts for both India and Nigeria, positioning them among the strongest performers in their respective regions as global growth remains steady despite lingering trade tensions.

In its January 2026 World Economic Outlook update, the IMF raised India's FY26 growth estimate by 0.7 percentage points to 7.3%, citing a "better-than-expected outturn in the third quarter" and strong momentum heading into the final months of the fiscal year. The Fund expects growth to moderate to 6.4% in both 2026 and 2027 "as cyclical and temporary factors wane".[1][2][3]

Nigeria's 2026 growth outlook was raised to 4.4% from 4.2% projected in October, with the IMF citing improved macroeconomic stability and the government's ongoing reform efforts.[4][5][6]

items.title: Prince Harry returns to court in battle with British tabloids
items.description: Prince Harry has returned to court in London in his third and final attempt to tame the British tabloids through the legal system.

items.title: Excitons outperform light for engineering quantum materials

featured_image.name: Quantum engineers turn theory into physics via exciton ...

items.description:
A breakthrough in Floquet engineering demonstrates that excitons—quasiparticles formed within semiconductors—can modify material properties far more efficiently than light alone, potentially opening a new path to creating quantum materials on demand.

Researchers from the Okinawa Institute of Science and Technology (OIST) and Stanford University have shown that exciton-driven Floquet effects in monolayer semiconductors are two orders of magnitude stronger and last longer than effects achieved with conventional light-based methods, according to findings published in Nature Physics on January 18, 2026.[1]

items.title: Trump sends letter to Norway amid Greenland threats
items.description: President Donald Trump sends a letter to the Norwegian Prime Minister Jonas Gahr Støre saying he no longer feels obligated to think purely of peace.

items.title: EU holds off on trade 'bazooka' as Trump tariffs loom

featured_image.name: European leaders warn Trump's Greenland tariffs threaten ... - NPR

items.description:
The European Union is weighing tariffs on up to €93 billion ($108 billion) worth of American goods and considering unprecedented trade countermeasures after President Donald Trump threatened to impose a 10% levy on eight European countries unless Washington is allowed to purchase Greenland.

EU ambassadors from all 27 member states convened for an emergency meeting in Brussels on Sunday following Trump's announcement on Saturday that tariffs would take effect February 1 on Denmark, Norway, Sweden, France, Germany, the United Kingdom, the Netherlands, and Finland. The president warned the rate would rise to 25% by June 1 unless a deal is reached for the "Complete and Total purchase of Greenland."[1][2][3][4][5]

items.description: Tensions between the United States and Greenland's allies reach a new high, with threats of increasing tariffs after European troops were sent to the island.

items.title: Two trains collide in Spain, killing at least 21

featured_image.name: High-speed train crash in southern Spain leaves at least ...

items.description:
At least 21 people were killed and up to 100 injured when two high-speed trains collided in southern Spain on Sunday evening after one derailed and crossed into the path of an oncoming service, prompting authorities to suspend all rail traffic between Madrid and the Andalusia region.

The crash occurred at approximately 6:40 p.m. local time near the town of Adamuz in Córdoba province when an Iryo train traveling from Málaga to Madrid derailed and struck a Renfe train heading from Madrid to Huelva, according to Spanish rail network operator Adif. Both trains were carrying hundreds of passengers—roughly 300 on the Iryo service and around 100 to 200 on the Renfe train.[1][2][3][4]

Spain's Transport Minister Óscar Puente confirmed the death toll after midnight, stating that all survivors had been rescued from the wreckage. Among those killed was the driver of the Renfe train, according to state broadcaster Televisión Española. Officials said 25 of the injured sustained serious wounds, with 73 passengers transported to six different hospitals.[2][5][6][4][7]

items.title: Former Labor strategist Tim Picton dies after alleged assault
items.description: Former Labor strategist Tim Picton dies in hospital, weeks after he was allegedly assaulted outside a Perth nightclub.

items.title: EU weighs €93B tariffs in response to Trump's Greenland threats

featured_image.name: EU countries consider retaliatory tariffs after Trump's ...

items.description:
European Union capitals are considering imposing €93 billion ($108 billion) in retaliatory tariffs against the United States and restricting American companies from accessing the bloc's market in response to President Donald Trump's tariff threats targeting NATO allies who oppose his campaign to acquire Greenland, according to the Financial Times.[1][2][3]

The escalating standoff marks one of the most serious crises in transatlantic relations in recent memory, with European leaders abandoning what officials described as an "appeasement" strategy toward the Trump administration.[3][4]

items.title: Sequoia backs Anthropic, breaking VC tradition on rival bets

featured_image.name: Sequoia to invest in Anthropic, breaking VC taboo on backing ...

items.description:
Sequoia Capital is joining a blockbuster funding round for Anthropic that values the AI startup at $350 billion, according to the Financial Times. The move breaks with long-standing venture capital tradition by backing a direct competitor to OpenAI and xAI, both of which are already in Sequoia's portfolio.[1][2]

The funding round is led by Singapore's sovereign wealth fund GIC and U.S. investor Coatue, with each contributing $1.5 billion. Anthropic is targeting a total raise of $25 billion or more, which would close to double its $183 billion valuation from September's Series F round.[3][4][5][1]
